headline.main: United States Ranks Last on Breast-Feeding Support

docs.abstract: A new Save the Children report ranks the United States last among 36 industrialized nations on its breast-feeding policies. Are you surprised?
docs.snippet: A new Save the Children report ranks the United States last among 36 industrialized nations on its breast-feeding policies. Are you surprised?

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.

docs.lead_paragraph: A national survey of more than 12,000 students in grades 5 to 10 has found that television viewing is associated not only with unhealthy snacking while watching, but also with unhealthy eating at all times. Researchers asked the children how much TV they watched; how often they snacked while watching; how often they ate fruits, vegetables and candy and drank soda; and how often they skipped breakfast.

headline.main: Vital Signs: Childhood: TV and Unhealthy Diets Have Stronger Link

docs.abstract: Study in journal Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine finds that television viewing among children is associated with unhealthy snacking, as well as lower odds of eating fruits and vegetables daily. (S)l

docs.lead_paragraph: THE FACTS When it comes to the health-promoting effects of red wine, its potential to protect against heart disease tends to get all the attention. But there are some who see it as a sort of probiotic delivery system, capable of benefiting the stomach as well.

headline.main: Really? The Claim: Red Wine Is Good For The Stomach.

docs.abstract: Research suggests that red wine may improve digestive health. (M)
